1.0    Introduction

The Rohm and Haas Company Croydon Plant is committed to operating and maintaining processes safely and responsibly.  Our continuing work to prevent accidents and releases from occurring, as well as our preparations to respond to incidents should occur, help to ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This summary provides an overview of the risk management activities at the Croydon Plant, and a discussion of our response to the EPAA?s Risk Management Program.  This summary includes:

2.0    General Facility Information
3.0    The EPAA?s Risk Management Program
4.0    Regulated Substances
5.0    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy
6.0    The Rohm and Haas Croydon Plant Accident Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
7.0    Five Year Accident History
8.0    Emergency Response Program

2.0    General Facility Information

The Croydon Plant is a specialty chemical manufacturing facility located in the Bristol Township, Bucks County, Pennsylvania.  The plant was built in 1969 and is part of a larger site, the Bristol Facility originally built in 1909.  Today, the Bristol Facility includes the Croydon plant, the polymers solvent based acrylic production facility, and corporate engineering group.  The Croydon Plant shares many of the services provided at the Bristol Facility including a unified emergency response network.  Of the total site area of 800+ acres, only 250 acres are in actual usage with the balance of the area utilized as open space accommodating a variety of plant and animal species.

The Croydon Plant produces over 100 different products which are sold to other manufacturers who use them as key components in consumer products.  The Croydon Plant produces aqueous based acrylic emulsion products which are used as coatings and binders.  Emulsion coating products are used in interior and exterior latex paint and traffic line formulatio

ns.  In addition, these products are found in floor polishes, adhesives, inks, coatings and binders for paper products, as well as caulking, cement and concrete.  The Croydon Plant produces environmentally friendly coating products.

Croydon Plant produces more than 350 million pounds of product annually.   The facilityA?s production units employ 129 personnel.  The plant works with the Bristol Facility contributing to a variety of charitable organizations within the community.   The Bristol Facility works closely with its Community Advisory Council (CAC) to identify the needs and community concerns.

3.0    The EPAA?s Risk Management Program

In a series of rules promulgated between 1994 and 1998, and updated in 2004, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency established the Risk Management Program (RMP) under the Clean Air Act containing a list of toxic and flammable chemicals.  Facilities that manage more than a threshold amount of a listed chemical are subject to the RMP.  Covered facilities must assess the risks associated with their management of the listed chemicals and produce a plan to prevent releases and accidents.  In order to assist in emergency planning, covered facilities must evaluate A?worst caseA? and A?alternate caseA? scenarios that would result from the release of a listed chemical.  . 

4.0    Regulated Substances

The Croydon Plant uses three RMP toxic chemicals: 
A?    Acrylonitrile monomer
A?    Vinyl Acetate monomer
A?    Aqueous ammonia. 


5.0    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy       

Rohm and Haas Croydon Plant has a long standing commitment to provide a safe workplace and to prevent accidental releases.  This commitment is set forth in Rohm and Haas environmental, health and safety policies:

A?    We will meet or exceed all applicable laws and regulations, participate in voluntary initiatives such as Responsible CareA? and strive for continual improvement in our Environmental, Health, and Safety performance.

A?    We will ensure o

ur worldwide operations and products are free from significant risks to the health and safety of our employees, customers, carriers, distributors, the general public, and to the environment.
    
A?    We will communicate, listen and be responsive to our employees, customers, neighbors, and governments, and strive to eliminate or reduce emissions, discharges, and wastes from every stage of our operations.

A?    We will provide our employees with a safe workplace and support their efforts to work safely.

A?    We will strive to eliminate or reduce emissions, discharges, and waste from every stage of our operations.

The types of risk management programs required by the RMP have long been in place at the Croydon Plant.  Safe operation is a plant and company priority, and is reflected in policies as well as everyday activities. 

6.0    The Rohm and Haas Croydon Plant Accident Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps  

Croydon Plant maintains a number of accident prevention programs in order to ensure safe operation of all processes.  The Croydon Plant complies with OSHAA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) rule, which is nearly identical to EPAA?s Risk Management Program (RMP) rule. Additionally, the Plant follows corporate and plant-specific safety standards, (which in some cases are more stringent than the OSHA general safety standards), while also complying with EPA, DOT, and state requirements.  The Croydon Plant also participates in OSHAA?s Voluntary Protection Program which focuses on continued workplace safety practices.  The following items are part of our ongoing program to prevent releases and incidents for RMP toxic chemicals as well as any other chemicals:  

6.1     Employee Participation A?  Employees are involved in many activities to continuously improve plant safety.   Employees participate in safety committees, job safety analysis, audits, design and pre-startup safety reviews, process hazard analysis, training, procedure development and monthly safe

ty meetings.

6.2    Process Hazard Analysis - Various process hazard analysis techniques are used to 
identify and analyze the potential hazards associated with the chemicals and processes we use. Corrective action plans are developed and implemented as part of the analyses and updated a minimum of every five years.  Safety systems are designed into the processes.  These are designed to create several layers of protection, so that if one system fails other systems will maintain the process in a safe state.  These engineering and administrative controls help prevent releases of chemicals: 

A?    Redundant safety systems and instrumentation, particularly for tank level systems
A?    Automatic shutdown devices that are triggered if critical safety equipment malfunctions
A?    Secondary containment for storage tanks
A?    Alarm systems and automatic shutdown devices for critical control parameters 
A?    Pressure relief devices to prevent over pressurization
A?    Fire protection systems
A?    Operator attendance of unloading operations
A?    Permit system to control work in hazardous areas
A?    Work preplanning and safety reviews


6.3    Operating Procedures A? Operating procedures have been developed for all processes to insure safe operation.  Employees that operate the manufacturing process are included in the development, training, and periodic review of these procedures.   Our processes are ISO A? 9000 certified. 

6.4    Employee Training A? Training programs have been developed and implemented  to ensure that all affected employees understand the hazards of the chemicals used and the required safe handling procedures. Employees involved in operating the manufacturing processes are trained, tested, qualified and certified at least once every 3 years as required by OSHA PSM.      
  
6.5    Mechanical Integrity A? This program was established to ensure the integrity of process equipment.  Elements of this program include:

A?    Identification and categorization of equipment and instrumentation
A?    Ins

pections and tests
A?    Establishment of inspection frequencies
A?    Development and application of maintenance procedures
A?    Training of maintenance personnel
A?    Documentation of tests and inspection results

6.6    Pre-Startup Safety Reviews A? Safety reviews of new processes, major projects, and new chemicals are conducted to ensure safe transition into the manufacturing process.  

6.7    Hot Work Permit A? This system manages welding, cutting, brazing and other ignition sources throughout the plant to prevent fires and explosions.

6.8    Management of Change A? This procedure is in place to properly manage the changes involving processes, chemicals, technology, people, equipment or facilities. 

6.9    Contractor Training and Safety Reviews A? Contractors are evaluated to ensure they have the appropriate job skills, knowledge, training, and certification to perform their assigned work safely.  The safety performance of contractors is periodically reviewed.

6.10    Incident Investigation A? Any incidents or near misses involving the release of hazardous materials are investigated by a team of skilled and knowledgeable plant personnel.  These investigations identify corrective actions, evaluate our management systems and are documented and communicated as appropriate throughout the company in a narrative report.  Any required corrective actions are tracked for timely completion.

6.11    Compliance Audits A? Audits of our Process Safety Management System and RMP are conducted  every three years.  These audits review accident prevention activities to ensure the requirements of the programs are being met. 

7.0    Five Year Accident History

The Rohm and Haas Croydon Plant has had no events meeting the criteria established by the RMP rule during the last five years.

8.0    Emergency Response Program 

The Rohm and Haas Croydon Plant plan is incorporated into a unified emergency response plan for the Bristol Facility.  This Consolidated Emergency Response Plan is  coordinated with the Bucks

and Burlington County Local Emergency Planning Committees (LEPC), Bristol Township, and Croydon Fire Company.  New employees are trained on handling emergencies prior to working in a process area and plant personnel review the plan annually.  The Bristol Facility has an extensive alarm system, which is monitored by ADT.   The facility has emergency service technicians on site at all times.   ADT will call the emergency service technician or the fire department depending on the type of alarm.   The facility has an on-site fire brigade, mobile fire suppression vehicles, Hazmat Technicians as well as certified emergency medical personnel. The site has mobile foam capabilities to control vapor release.  All emergency response personnel receive ongoing training.  The facility has 24-hour emergency response capabilities and can respond to both on-site and transportation off-site hazardous materials releases.  The facility is also part of the Rohm and Haas regional response network and provides offsite response into the community when requested on a mutual aid basis.  Facility emergency response personnel have radio communications with the Bucks County 911 center.  Emergency response personnel can be self dispatched, or dispatched through the County 911 center.  The Complex is also able to access the Community Alerting Network (CAN) through the Bristol Township Emergency Management Department.   Plant drill and mutual aid response activities are practiced annually.   In order to improve security, the plant conducted a Security Vulnerability Analysis in 2003, and submitted a Department of Homeland Security SVA analysis in January 2009.    

9.0    Planned Changes to Improve Safety 

The  focus on safety is strong throughout the Rohm and Haas Company.  Rohm and Haas continuously looks for ways to reduce risks and to improve safety performance.  This includes the improvements in control technology, inspections, training, and maintenance of process equipment. Croydon Plant safet

y program is integrated into all parts of plant operation and involves the identification and implementation of  ways to improve safety performance.   Major improvements since the last submission included increased instrumentation of processes.
